Value Prop

Enterprise administrators will be able to assign an organization role (custom or pre-defined) to an enterprise team against multiple organizations at once. Organization administrators will be unable to remove or bypass this assignment, ensuring that critical teams have the access they require.

Expected Outcome

If it is easier to manage access to multiple organizations at the same time, administrators should be able to divide their estate into multiple organizations. This in turn helps with delegation and separation of concerns without losing the ability to collaborate across the organizations.
items.title: Assign organization roles to a team across multiple organizations - [Public Preview]

items.content_html:
Summary

GitHub Enterprise Importer (GEI) currently imposes the following repository size limits:

  • 10 GB size limit for a Git repository: This limit only applies to the source code. To check if the repository archive is over the limit, use the git-sizer tool and review the total blob size in the output.
  • 10 GB limit for metadata: The Importer cannot migrate repositories with more than 10 GB of metadata. Metadata includes issues, pull requests, releases, and attachments.

To support the migration of larger repositories to GitHub and between GitHub products, we will be increasing the repository size limits to:

  • 40 GB size limit for a Git repository
  • 40 GB limit for metadata

Intended Outcome

Customers will be capable of migrating larger repositories using GEI. In doing so, GitHub migration tooling is expanding to help customers operating large monorepos migrate to GitHub or between GitHub products.

How will it work?

This ship will not change how GEI is used. Customers can continue using GEI using the same instructions documented in our documentation on GitHub Enterprise Importer.
items.title: Increase GitHub Enterprise Importer's (GEI) repository size limit to 40GB (Preview)

items.content_html:
Summary

We're enhancing user experience and data accessibility with new CSV export functionality on the security overview dashboard and secret scanning metrics page at the organization level. This functionality will enable you to easily download detailed data on alerts from the overview dashboard and data regarding secrets blocked by push protection on the secret scanning metrics page.

Intended Outcome

This feature empowers you with the tools to perform offline analysis of alerts and and secrets blocked by push protection. By exporting this data to a CSV file, you will gain the ability to:

  • conduct in-depth offline analysis
  • compare and integrate data with external systems
  • archive data for compliance and historical analysis

How will it work?

You'll find an "Export to CSV" button on both the security overview dashboard and the secret scanning metrics page. Clicking this button will automatically download the underlying data that backs the report, which will reflect the filters currently applied to the respective pages. Downloads are permitted only for repositories where you have the appropriate permission.

Looking forward, we plan to expand this functionality to include API access, enabling automated data retrieval.
items.title: Export organization-level code security alerts and push protection data to to CSV

items.content_html:
Summary

GitHub Environments are typically used with Actions workflows to describe a general deployment target like production, testing, staging, or development to which an application or service (s) is deployed to. Currently we support “deployment protection rules” which can be configured to protect environments and their associated secrets & variables from getting accessed by unintended deployments. And also to have more controlled deployment rollouts based on certain predefined criteria evaluated by each of the rules.

However, Developers and DevOps managers often need to centrally configure and manage protection rules on their environments across their teams and applications beyond the GitHub boundaries of organizations and repositories.

To enable "Management of Environments at Scale", we are coming up with a new delightful configuration experience for defining and managing groups of Environments across repositories coupled with powerful settings management across Environments.

Intended Outcome

With this new cross-repo management experience for Environments, Developers and DevOps managers would be enabled to

  • group environments within/across repos by adding metadata to environments across repositories in your organization.
  • easily and consistently apply protection rules on groups of environments across repositories in order to have a standard set of configurations and settings across all environments within the group.
  • filter deployment views by groups of Environments.

How will it work?

We are enabling a new central management experience for Environments across repositories by

  • Extending rulesets to support central configurations on “protected Environments”
  • Supporting custom properties to group Environments and configure rulesets
items.title: Actions: Managing Environments at Scale

items.content_html:
Summary

macOS 15 is now available in public beta for GitHub-hosted runners.

Intended Outcome

Apple developers require the latest version of macOS and Xcode now have access to newer versions

How will it work?

Update the runs-on: key in you workflow file to macos-15, macos-15-large, or macos-15-xlarge

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: macos-15
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Build
        run: swift build
      - name: Run tests
        run: swift test
items.title: Actions: macOS 15 is now available for GitHub-hosted runners (Preview)

items.content_html:
Summary

macOS 15 is now generally available for GitHub-hosted runners. It will also become the latest macOS runner image with workflows migrating from November 2024 through December 2024.

Intended Outcome

Apple developers require the latest version of macOS and Xcode now have access to newer versions

How will it work?

Actions workflows using the macos-latest label will incrementally transition from macOS 14 to macOS 15 beginning November 2024 and will conclude before the end of December 2024. This also applies to larger macOS runners, for which the following YAML workflow labels can be used:

  • macos-latest-xlarge
  • macos-latest-large
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: macos-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Build
        run: swift build
      - name: Run tests
        run: swift test

To use macOS 15 directly, update the runs-on: key in you workflow file to macos-15, macos-15-large, or macos-15-xlarge

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: macos-14
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Build
        run: swift build
      - name: Run tests
        run: swift test
items.title: Actions: macOS 15 is now available for GitHub-hosted runners (GA)

With these new runner options, developers can be confident that their apps will be compatible with past, present, and future software requirements, while also increasing their development velocity.

GitHub Actions makes it easy for developers to build and deploy their applications using the latest Apple technologies. With GitHub Actions, developers can seamlessly integrate their workflows and take advantage of the latest Apple technologies to build and deploy their applications with ease.
items.title: M2 Pro Powered GitHub hosted runners [Public Preview]

items.content_html:
Summary

GitHub is excited to announce the GA of M2 pro powered macOS runners. Our larger macOS runners have been upgraded to include M2 Pro Mac Minis, which will provide Apple developers with improved performance to build and test iOS apps. With these new runner options, developers can be confident that their apps will be compatible with past, present, and future software requirements, while also increasing their development velocity.

Intended Outcome

GitHub Actions makes it easy for developers to build and deploy their applications using the latest Apple technologies. With GitHub Actions, developers can seamlessly integrate their workflows and take advantage of the latest Apple technologies to build and deploy their applications with ease

How will it work?

To start using M2 Pro powered macOS runners, simply update the runs-on: key in your Actions workflow file to macos-15-xlarge. This will ensure that your jobs target the new runner.
items.title: Actions: M2 Pro Powered macOS runners (GA)

items.content_html:
Summary

Larger macOS runners are now available in the Runner group management experience providing more controls for managing runners holistically.

Intended Outcome

Ensure that creating and managing runners, regardless of type (macOS, Ubuntu, Windows), is a seamless experience. Developers will have the ability to choose from multiple machine sizes and images for their macOS workflow runs.

How will it work?

To set up a new macOS runner, navigate to the Actions section within the Policies section of your enterprise or organization. Select "New runner" and choose macOS as the platform. You can then select the image, machine size, and set concurrency limits from there. For more information, refer to our documentation:

  • Managing larger runners
  • Control access to larger runners
items.title: Actions: macOS runners are now available in runner groups

items.content_html:
Summary

GitHub is thrilled to announce the availability of private networking for hosted macOS runners. This feature allows users to assign a set of static IPs to a runner or runner group, and also provides the option to use Azure private networking for macOS runners. By executing workflows behind the protection of the Azure Virtual Network, customers can ensure additional network security for workflows that require access to private resources within their network. This will be particularly useful for developers who have enabled IP allow lists, as they can now assign a specific set of static IPs to macOS runners.

Intended Outcome

GitHub now offers private networking capabilities for hosted macOS runners, which enables users to securely access private resources within their on-prem or cloud-based locations, such as databases, artifactory, storage accounts, or APIs. Developers can enforce network security policies and outbound access rules on the runners, which can help to reduce data exfiltration risks. Additionally, developers can isolate their build traffic from the public internet and route it through their existing private network connections (such as VPN or ExpressRoute).

How will it work?

The process of assigning static IPs or setting up Azure private networking for macOS runners is the same as it is for Ubuntu and Windows runners. For more information, please refer to our documentation.

  • Azure Private Networking
  • Assigning static IPs
items.title: Actions: Private networking for GitHub-hosted macOS runners

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Secret scanning has controls that allow you to specify which teams or roles have the ability to bypass push protection. These controls introduce a review and approval cycle for pushes containing secrets from all other contributors.

Expected Outcome

Push protection bypass controls gives security teams an extra check to prevent secret leaks, ensuring push protection blocks are not accidentally bypassed.
items.title: Secret scanning: delegated bypass for push protection [GA]

items.content_html:
Summary

Actions will add the ability to run your workflow jobs on the latest Ubuntu 24.04 version from Canonical. With this release the Ubuntu 24 image will also become the latest Ubuntu runner image with workflows migrating in September 2024.

Intended Outcome

Developers will be able to build and test their code on the latest version of Ubuntu, while using the latest tag within their Actions job

How will it work?

Actions workflows using the ubuntu-latest label will incrementally transition from Ubuntu 22 to Ubuntu 24 beginning September 2024.

To use the Ubuntu 24 image directly, update the runs-on: key in you workflow file to ubuntu-24.04
To run on the -latest tag, use the ubuntu-latest label.

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Run a one-line script
        run: echo Hello from Octo Organization
items.title: Actions: Ubuntu 24 on GitHub-hosted runners (GA)

items.content_html:
Summary

Our current overview dashboard is aggregating and displaying data at the organization level, encompassing all repositories within the organization. To provide a more comprehensive view for larger enterprises, we aim to build an enterprise-level dashboard to aggregate and present data across all organizations within an enterprise. This enterprise-level dashboard will offer a macro view of application security metrics, aiding in broader strategic decisions and analyses.

Intended Outcome

Enterprise users require the ability to analyze data across their enterprise. This feature will give application security users the ability to view aggregated data from all organizations within my enterprise in a single, unified dashboard so that they can easily compare and analyze metrics at an enterprise scale to make informed, overarching decisions regarding security and development practices.

How will it work?

Security managers and organization owners will be able to access an overview of code security metrics through the enterprise account page. This dashboard will offer a consolidated view of security metrics across organizations that are currently only available at the organization level.

In cases where users have access to multiple organizations, they will have the flexibility of filtering by organization.
items.title: Enterprise-level overview dashboard [Public Beta]

items.content_html:
Summary

While organization owners can create custom organization roles to control their users' access to the organization, we've found that there are common patterns that most organizations need. These roles will be built in to every GitHub organization, and available to all organizations, both enterprise and free, to provide a "batteries included" least-privilege setup.

We'll be adding new roles over time as features within GitHub add granular management. At launch, though, we'll have a set of five organization-wide base roles, which grant read, triage, write, maintain, or admin privileges against every repository in the organization. These can be assigned to organization members as well as organization teams.
items.title: Pre-defined organization roles

items.content_html:
Summary

With this feature, you can now group alerts by close reasons on the alert trends report and apply filters on the overview page based on close reason. This improvement encompasses alerts from all GitHub security tools—Dependabot, CodeQL, secret scanning—as well as third-party alerts.

Intended Outcome

Security managers often grapple with the high volume of closed alerts, making it difficult to extract meaningful insights. Key questions like, "How many alerts were dismissed as false positives?" or "How many were actually remediated?" can now be answered effortlessly. This feature aims to empower security managers to monitor, track, and audit resolved alerts with precision, ultimately enhancing your organization's ability to address and reduce vulnerabilities.

How will it work?

The updated security overview dashboard will introduce a new "Close Reason" grouping option within the alert trends graph. Additionally, you can apply filters using close reasons on both the dashboard and individual alert pages. For instance, you can display alerts marked as "risk accepted" using the filter close-reason:risk-accepted, allowing for a more granular and focused analysis of security alerts.

New close reason alert trends grouping:
items.title: Close reasons trends grouping and filters for the overview dashboard

items.content_html:
Summary

Elevate your enterprise's security with this new organization-level report, designed to proactively monitor and track preventative remediation activities and autofix metrics, ensuring vulnerabilities are addressed swiftly and efficiently. Additionally, this report is also designed to highlight the substantial value and return on investment that GitHub Advanced Security prevention tactics brings to your security operations.

Intended Outcome

Many security managers struggle to quantify the preventative impact of GitHub Advanced Security, understand the value that autofix delivers and communicate its benefits effectively. Wit this report, you'll have the data-driven metrics at your fingertips to effectively drive prevention strategies, demonstrate impact, and, ultimately, significantly mitigate enterprise risks.

How will it work?

Introducing a new, comprehensive report that aggregates CodeQL pull request alerts and breaks them down by repository, providing deep insights into your security landscape. This report will feature key metrics, including the most prevalent rules triggering pull request alerts, and detailed breakdowns of alert statuses—unresolved, merged, dismissed, and specifically, those fixed with or without autofix. Additionally, it will track and display trends in pull request alert volumes, offering a historical view that can be filtered extensively to suit your analytical needs.

Prototype report
items.title: Organization-level CodeQL pull request alerts report

items.content_html:
Summary

Enhance your understanding of your security landscape with our newly redesigned enterprise-level overview dashboard. This intuitive interface categorizes your security insights into three distinct, streamlined domains: detection, remediation, and prevention. Experience enhanced visibility with top-line metrics from GitHub Advanced Security’s preventative features such as secret scanning’s push protection and CodeQL’s alerts in pull requests. This refined design ensures that you can quickly and easily understand your security metrics, enabling more effective decision-making at a glance.

Intended Outcome

Security managers often struggle to effectively quantify and communicate the critical metrics from the key security activities. This redesigned dashboard makes it straightforward to navigate and understand the current status of your security operations. With immediate access to tangible metrics and insights, this feature empowers you to proactively manage prevention and remediation efforts, demonstrate their impact, and ultimately reduce your enterprise's risk exposure significantly.

How will it work?

The updated security overview dashboard introduces a dedicated prevention section, displaying essential metrics. You'll find vital indicators such as the number of vulnerabilities detected in pull requests, the tally of alerts resolved through autofix, and the count of secrets proactively blocked. Further, the existing dashboard components for detection and remediation have been refined to seamlessly integrate with this new structure. This comprehensive and actionable view enables your team to continually optimize and fortify your security protocols.
items.title: Enterprise-level overview dashboard organized by key domain
